Award.AwardTitle: Travel support for the 12th International Conference on Fundamentals of Adsorption

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1551591
Neimark, Alexander V.


Travel funds are requested to partially support approximately 25 graduate students and young faculty to participate in the 12 International Conference on Fundamentals of Adsorption (FOA12) in Germany from May 29-June 3, 2016. In order to encourage US participation in this critical conference,funding is requested to partially defray the travel costs of US participants from academia and nonprofit research institutions. The goal is to provide partial support to about 25 US researchers from this grant

Technological advances in energy, biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and environmental applications of adsorption will be facilitated by FOA12 through sharing of new adsorption-related scientific information at the highest level. Additional broader impacts will be associated with the participation of young faculty and graduate students (facilitated by the proposed travel funds), and their exposure to the frontiers of adsorption science and technology in a truly interdisciplinary and international scientific gathering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant provided partial travel support to the members of US delegation at the 12th International Conference on the Fundamentals of Adsorption (FOA12) held in Friedrichshafen at Lake Constance in Germany, May 29–June 3, 2016. The FOA Conference is the premier international meeting in the field of Adsorption. The conference is held every three years under the auspices of the International Adsorption Society (IAS). A hallmark of the conference is its comprehensive coverage of the spectrum of fundamental research and applications of adsorption, ranging from molecular modeling and simulation of fluids adsorbed in porous materials to the design of pressure swing adsorption systems for industrial gas separation processes. FOA12 was attended by 319 delegates, including 92 students, from 32 countries throughout the World. The grant made possible for 8 graduate students, 1 postdoc, and 3 faculty members from US Universities to attend the conference, present their research work, and most importantly to get involved into the various activities of the international scientific community. The conference provided multiple opportunities for their training and professional development though critical assessment of their scientific results during discussion and poster sessions, direct interactions with the leaders in the field, including industrial participants. The exposure to the frontiers of adsorption science and technology in a truly interdisciplinary and international scientific gathering helped young scientists better understand the validity of their research and opportunity for further carrier development.
